text: the big news in the financial world
today is that the government came out
and bailed out Citigroup over the
weekend they went late in the night to
do it they still haven't worked out the
details but the markets are thrilled by
it the result is the government is going
to put another 20 billion dollars into
Citigroup and perhaps more importantly
they're going to guarantee a lot of
citigroup's assets so that if they go
down much more the government will bear
most of the losses once again the
government has walked in to reassure
markets that a big bank in this country
is not in danger of failing what this
shows is that there's still a lot of
doubt about the quality of the assets
these banks have and that the government
is feeling its way it's never done this
before it hopes it never asked to do it
again the government can keep doing this
I suppose as long as it once one of the
great advantages the government has is
it as a dollar printing press they can
write checks for as many dollars as they
want and they can print dollars now if
they do too much of that eventually we
may have rampant inflation but that's
the problem down the line and that's not
something they're worrying about this
week and now of course we're moving on
we're about to have a new administration
take over today as it happened
president-elect Obama introduced his
economic team the new treasury secretary
is tim geithner a man who is viewed as
very smart and a man who's been
intimately involved in all the bailout
discussions as president of the New York
Fed this should be the easy part bailing
out the system the hard part is going to
be to get it functioning again and get
the economy moving and that's going to
be a big challenge he and the rest of
the administration will face for the New
York Times this is Floyd Norris
